references: SFLv2 demonstrates significant constraints in managing positive labels, as evidenced by the results presented in TableÂ I. To tackle this challenge, we introduce an enhanced version of the SFLv2, which we call SFPL. The algorithm of SFPL is depicted in AlgorithmÂ 1 andÂ 2. It comprises four main functions: Client, ClientFedServer, GlobalCollectorFunction, and ServerSideModelFunction. A brief description of each componentâ€™s functionality, illustrated in Figure 1, is presented in the following:

This section presents an analysis of SFLv2â€™s failures. This study is applicable to other SFL variants, such as SFLv1. SFLv2 suffers due to the following when engaged in a learning scenario with only positively labeled data (see TableÂ I).

S4.T2.caption: TABLE II: Total cost analysis of the three DCML approaches for one global epoch.
references: This section presents an analysis of communication cost and model training time for SFPL, SFLv2, and FL. Let Nğ‘N represent the number of clients, ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} denote the total size of the dataset, qğ‘q be the size of the smashed layer, Rğ‘…R be the communication rate, and Tğ‘‡T be the time required for one forward and backward propagation on the full model using a dataset of size ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} (for any architecture). Let Tfedavgsubscriptğ‘‡fedavgT_{\text{fedavg}} denote the time required for full model aggregation (with Tfedavg2subscriptğ‘‡fedavg2\frac{T_{\text{fedavg}}}{2} being the aggregation time for client-side model aggregation only), |ğ–|ğ–|\mathbf{W}| represent the size of the full model, and Î²ğ›½\beta be the fraction of the full modelâ€™s size available in a client for SFPL/SFL, i.e., |ğ–C|=Î²â€‹|ğ–|superscriptğ–Cğ›½ğ–\left|\mathbf{W}^{\mathrm{C}}\right|=\beta|\mathbf{W}|. The term 2â€‹Î²â€‹|W|2ğ›½W2\beta|\mathrm{W}| indicates the communication cost per client due to the download and upload of the client-side model updates before and after training, respectively. Despite the addition of a global collector function, the latency incurred can be considered negligible due to its location on the same server as the server-side model function. The results are presented in Table II. As observed in the table, the total training time cost increases in the order of FL << SFLv2 == SFPL as the number of clients (Nğ‘N) increases.

references: This section delineates the empirical studyâ€™s dataset, model architecture, and initialization strategy, followed by the comparative experimental results of the proposed SFPL framework, SFLv2, and FedAws. Further examinations to substantiate the proposed frameworkâ€™s efficacy under diverse conditions are also presented. Our experiments employ the CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 image datasets [9], each containing 50,000 training and 10,000 test images of 3072 dimensions (32Ã—32)3232(32\times 32). To mitigate overfitting, random horizontal flipping, rotation, normalization, and cropping were applied. Following the data partitioning strategy in SectionÂ IV, each client corresponds to a single class; thus, for CIFAR-10, 10 clients are considered, while for CIFAR-100, 100 clients are selected. As outlined in TableÂ III, we utilized three primary model architectures, R8, R32, and R56 [12], because of the discrete â€blocksâ€ structure which facilitates model partitioning.

Server flops and parameters escalated with architectural complexity (Table IV). references: The empirical findings presented in TableÂ V demonstrate the efficacy of SFPL in mitigating the constraints inherent in the SFLv2 learning framework while training DL models solely utilizing positive labels. In the CIFAR-100 dataset, SFLv2 reported relatively low accuracies, approximately 1.4% for the R56 architecture and 2.05% for the R32 architecture, indicating a failure to learn effectively. Conversely, the SFPL framework significantly enhanced performance, achieving 72.16% and 66.77% accuracy for the R56 and R32 architectures respectively. A similar trend was observed in the CIFAR-10 dataset, with the R32 and R8 architecturesâ€™ accuracies stagnating at 10% under SFLv2, while SFPL significantly boosted them to 92.33% and 85.15%, respectively.

TableÂ V also presents additional evaluation metrics, such as Precision@1, recall, and F1 score, to corroborate that the DL models effectively learned all classes when employing the SFPL framework. Furthermore, the results indicate that the CMSD setup yielded superior outcomes compared to the RMSD setup during the testing phase, specifically when a single-class batch was utilized for model evaluation. Conversely, SFPLâ€™s performance declined when an IID batch was employed for testing.

references: Based on the results presented in TableÂ VI, it can be inferred that the RMSD setup outperforms the CMSD setup for all combinations of model architectures and datasets considered. These findings suggest that, within the context of the SFPL framework, performing BN layer aggregation during the client-side model aggregation process contributes to improved performance during the inference phase.

references: The results in TableÂ VIII demonstrate that the CMSD setup consistently surpasses the RMSD setup across all model architectures and dataset combinations, a considerable performance difference. This can be attributed to the utilization of non-IID testing datasets, enhancing the accuracy of the BN layerâ€™s statistics for the client-side model in the CMSD setup through the test batchâ€™s current mean and variance. Thus, in the SFPL framework for non-IID training and testing, aggregating the batch normalization layer during the training aggregation phase could potentially detriment the overall performance.
